You aren't giving enough credence to the notion that in some cases there is, in fact, a right or wrong decision. Considering the number of permabans he has under various accounts, it is reasonably to conclude that a permaban on the player is warranted.

In many cases you would be right to point out this logical fallacy, but in this case there is too much evidence supporting Riot's decision.

No, I am. His new account he was legit trying(and succeeding) to be less toxic to the point where you can actually say he improved. And if he was banned for a last straw type reason then maybe so, but he wasn't. He had not fed on purpose of any of his games, muted all instead of going on long rants in chat, etc.

He was legit banned because he started becoming extremely popular, and people didn't like that. And every single person messaging me is saying the same thing.

 Obviously ignorant of the timing of the ban (why ban him now when he's actually been at his lowest ever toxicity wise?) they are saying "well he was banned before so there's no chance he wasn't going to be less toxic now"

He was less toxic because he was trying to get a sub button on twitch, and noticeably successful in being less toxic. 

One can STILL come to the conclusion that he should be lifetime banned and i'm ok with that, but to say that there is no room for debate is just ignorance. The ignorance part is what is annoying because it is exactly the picture in the post that I was responding to.

Here's the part where you repeat how he's been banned and can't change, and ignore the rest of what I've said( have gotten a lot of posts/hate messages saying the same thing in varying levels of toxicity ). Or you could actually surprise me and say something new.

I don't know enough about the guy to say that he's gonna reform or whatever, but when I was looking for the VOD on his stream of him discovering his permaban, he burst my eardrums yelling about a ziggs getting caught out, and flaming in chat. So I wouldn't say that he's quite reformed.

And with a quick google search, as of March 11, he had been permabanned on 15 separate accounts (not a blanket ban at that time, 15 separate counts of him being permabanned) and made the argument that his toxicity is "kids are bad and need to know they're bad" Since then, I'd imagine he got more permabans after that.

Sure, there's room to debate about the justness of the ban (I think it's stupid to say that it's just because he's popular, since he's shown a long history of incredible toxicity) but to say that after that many times, and still very little actual reform, it's highly unlikely he ever will reform. 15 permabans should be enough to get you to realize you're being a dick, and if that's not the case, it's a good thing he can't ruin anymore games.

The stream doesn't matter, Riot just cares about what happens in the game. Twitch.TV doesn't work with Riot, and IIRC Twitch has warned Kaceytron so if she's gonna continue as she is she'll end up banned.

I am totally willing to accept the premise that he was trying to reform, and even succeeding to a certain extent. However, that doesn't mean that his past behavior should be excused. I can't comment as to the timing, and to be fair none of us can. For all I know Riot is instituting a new policy that people with X number of permabanned accounts will get banned as players, and his is the first case.

If I am understanding you correctly, your problem is with the timing of the ban. The part where I said there was little room for debate was the appropriateness of the ban. The totality of his behavior warranted it, even if the timing and circumstances sends a bad message.

The argument is not whether Tyler's perma-ban was justified, the argument is how Riot is willfully allowing the same behavior from other streamers to go unchecked.

Trick, Meteos, , IWD, QT, and Jensen are all just as toxic.

Nightblue has bought several accounts.

Sneaky spends his entire stream encouraging a homophobic and crude atmosphere. His thank you line for subs was "welcome to my butthole."

Kaceytron intentionally afks and feeds.

Other streams have knowingly DDosd and win traded.

Why are these players allowed to continue if Riot felt the need to not just ban, but perma ban Tyler?

Trick is toxic on stream only. The last time he was toxic in game he got slapped with a 2-week ban, he learned his lesson. Riot gives no fucks what you do on your personal stream, they in fact say a good way to prevent in-game toxicity is to vent out loud, which is exactly what he is doing. You could say he promotes selfish gameplay and mistrust of teammates but that's a separate matter.

QtPie also isn't toxic in game chat, only on his stream (and he's funny about it).

Kaceytron just plays to get a reaction and focuses her attention on her stream and responding to donations instead of the actual game. She simply isn't trying, just like a ton of other players in B5 with her, so Riot can't tell the difference and frankly don't seem to care about what happens in B5 anyway. Same with that  blonde streamer Athena who baits people into troll donations and screams at them
